"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Work in the humanities is a real path for change because political marketing doesn’t appeal to people’s emotions the way that art and stories do. And it seems like getting people to connect to their own humanity and feelings is essential to our ability to connect and have compassion for others. We don’t want to distract, overwhelm, or create burden by adding more to social media with the endless stories surrounding the social sphere; the intention is to replace the focus back on the faces of the change. We don’t expect to approach society as what we think we want them to think, but instead what we want them to do and let them form what they should do. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is an intergenerational fight. We don’t want to have reform that will end climate change and environmental struggles by 80%. We want 100% improvement. To humanize the lives of climate change. To put a face to its impacts. To shine a light on the mostly unseen. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Social photography … let there be light. WearthWhile embodies social photography to shine a light on stories that aren’t accessible to the public. Our aim is to create a tool that primes for a social reform or even a revolutionary movement. To be a part of that transition to fundamentally change how society views climate change and what is being done about it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The photoblog platform establishes positive and progressive discussion; at the heart of that is to include and recognize that people have feelings, experiences, beliefs and inner conflicts that influence the way they perceive and assimilate information. The internet offers opportunities for greater transparency and public participation into our changing climate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WearthWhile is a photoblog [story platform] that gives back the voice to the people. The commitment through this organization is to put emphasis on the opinions, impacts and experiences of people dealing with climate change and environmental problems. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Narrative offers a powerful means to engage an audience and convey complex concepts. title: Langholm Moor Community Buyout
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"LANGHOLM MOOR: COMMUNITY BUYOUT"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Supporting the south of Scotlands largest community land purchase. To manage Langholm Moor for ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Langholm Initiative have launched their crowdfunding campaign as they attempt the largest community buyout in the south of Scotland, hoping to bring 10,500 acres (about 5,600 football pitches) into community ownership. To be successful we need to raise the full purchase price by the end of October 2020."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout"}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received a great boost today (07/05/2020)  as the John Muir Trust has pledged £100,000 towards the purchase."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This project has the potential to act as a blueprint for other communities to place the environment at the heart of the decisions they make."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received widespread support from organisations such as the John Muir Trust, RSPB Scotland, The Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust and The Revive Coalition. In addition to this we have cross party political support for our plans, due to the positive goals relating to climate change, ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Locally over 20 organisations have written letters of support for the buyout."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kevin Cumming, the Langholm Initiative’s project leader said: “Our community plans here have international significance. At a time of climate emergency we are committing to undertake direct climate action including peatland restoration, ancient woodland restoration, the creation of new native woodlands and increasing the diversity of wildlife here”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“At this critical stage we are asking for the help of the public. We know it is a lot to ask at a time like this but if people can support us by donating to this project we will be demonstrating a more positive future for our children.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These ambitious plans will be taken forward with the creation of the new Tarras Valley Nature Reserve."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Our plans"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the past six months, a thorough feasibility study has been conducted by community land specialists Duncan MacPherson, Faye McLeod  & Willie McGhee, (a huge thank you to previous crowdfunding supporters for making this possible)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This has given us a vision for a bright future for Langholm moor,  a sustainable business plan for the  Langholm Initiative, and demonstrated real community and environmental benefits.  Our plans centre around creating the Tarras Valley Nature Reserve on the vast majority of the land. Here we will carry out positive climate action and provide a new focus for wildlife tourism and recreation in the south of Scotland.  On a smaller area of land nearest the town itself we will investigate appropriate small scale renewable energy (a single small turbine and a single small solar farm) and the development of a small eco-campsite. We will also investigate repurposing disused and dilapidated steadings for either small scale housing or modern business units, both of which are badly needed in Langholm (there have only been 6 new houses built in Langholm in the past 30 years)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This land also holds huge historical and cultural significance to local people who care passionately about its future. For over 250 years the community have marked the boundaries of the common land and this tradition still goes on today with the annual Common Riding celebration."}]}]

title: Researchers find that 1,000 metric tons of Microplastics fall on 11 protected areas in the US annually, equivalent to over 120 million plastic water bottles
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Plastic Rain Is the New Acid Rain"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These are unspoiled lands, collectively a great American conservation story. Yet an invisible menace is actually blowing through the air and falling via raindrops: Microplastic particles, tiny chunks (by definition, less than 5 millimeters long) of fragmented plastic bottles and microfibers that fray from clothes, all pollutants that get caught up in Earth’s atmospheric systems and deposited in the wilderness."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Writing today in the journal Science, researchers report a startling discovery: After collecting rainwater and air samples for 14 months, they calculated that over 1,000 metric tons of microplastic particles fall into 11 protected areas in the western US each year. That’s the equivalent of over 120 million plastic water bottles. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It further confirms an increasingly hellish scenario: Microplastics are blowing all over the world, landing in supposedly pure habitats, like the Arctic and the remote French Pyrenees. They’re flowing into the oceans via wastewater and tainting deep-sea ecosystems, and they’re even ejecting out of the water and blowing onto land in sea breezes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This new research comes with another troubling surprise: 30 percent of the sample particles were microbeads, tiny synthetic spheres that the United States banned from beauty products in 2015. The microbeads in the samples, though, were generally smaller than the ones you’d find in those products."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Scientists have been trying to figure out what happens to the world’s plastic pollution, nearly all of which seems to “disappear” in the environment. But studies like this one are showing that the stuff never truly goes away, it just gets shredded into smaller bits that disperse all over the world, perhaps spending many years cycling through different systems—air, land, and sea."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There’s still much that science has to learn about this microplastic cycle, but this much is clear: There’ll be no putting the plastic back in the bottle."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]}]

title: American Farmland Increasingly Owned by Investors
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Farmland is increasingly coming under the ownership of investors who often live hundreds if not thousands of miles away from the property itself. As farmland increases in price, upwards of tens of millions of dollars in many cases, land is being bought by those seeking to cash in at a later date as prices inevitably continue their upward trend. This has created many situations of poor land management. Farmers who are forced to lease their land rather than own it often will not invest in soil or water protection measures, such as cover crops, because they cannot be sure they will see the long term benefit of doing so. In addition, the investors who own the land have only a monetary attachment to the land and investing in these measures cuts into their profits from leasing the land. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Smarter land owners must realize that land managed in a more environmentally friendly way will be healthier land overall, and will be worth more as higher quality land than that which has been poorly managed."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is also linked to a push towards large scale corporate farms, some of which can own tens of thousands of acres of land irrigated with miles of pipelines. Farming operations on this scale are unobtainable for family owned farms and the pressure to sell to these corporations can often be a difficult but financially necessary choice for farmers struggling to compete in an ever technologically advancing time. title: Forests Naturally Migrate, But Not Fast Enough to Escape Human-Accelerated Climate Change
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Science write Zach St. George's new book, \"The Journeys of Trees\", illustrates how forests have exhibited a painstakingly slow migration for eons. As old trees die, new ones take root and thrive in more hospitable directions, slowly moving the forests. As temperatures near the equator increase, forests are moving slowly North, but too slowly to escape the devastating impacts of climate change at its current accelerated pace. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In places like California, Joshua trees may no longer be able to survive in Joshua Tree National Park - it will be too hot and dry. Ancient, giant Sequoia trees may no longer be found in Sequoia National Park. This begs the question - do we lose these species forever, or do we find new habitats and plant new groves? What of the species that already exist in these new areas? Many factors will come into play as scientists and environmentalists grapple with saving our iconic, widely cherished forests. content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As floods sweep across Assam, in north-east India, killing 73 and affecting 400,000 people across the state, 85% of the Kaziranga National Park and Tiger Reserve (KNPTR) remains submerged. So far, 125 animals have been rescued and 86 have died, including rhinos, deer and wild boar, in the sixth worst flood since 1988."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Yet, the annual floods are essential for the survival of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. Here are some of the reasons why."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is a riverine ecosystem, not a solid landmass-based ecosystem,” says P Sivakumar, Director, KNPTR, “The system won’t survive without water.” The entire area of Kaziranga—formed by alluvial deposits from the Brahmaputra and its tributaries—is centred around the river. The regenerative nature of floods helps replenish water bodies and maintain th landscape, a mix of wetlands, grasslands and semi-evergreen deciduous forests. The floodwaters also function as a breeding ground for fish. In a herbivore-dominated area like Kaziranga, it is important to maintain its grassland status. If it were not for the annual floods, the area would become a woodland. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But climate change and impractical infrastructure is beginning to spell disaster for the region, as more the damage done begins to outweigh the benefits. Many animals in the area are endangered, and are forced to seek refuge from areas that are deeper underwater than ever before due to unprecedented glacial melt, crossing the busy National Highway 37 that cuts through the park in the process. title: New Guinea has the highest plant diversity of any island in the world
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The first full inventory of plants on the world's largest tropical island reveals a treasure trove of flora."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"More than 13,000 species can be found on New Guinea, ranging from tiny orchids to giant tree ferns, two-thirds of which do not exist elsewhere.The findings, published in Nature, will be used to protect \"one of the last unknowns for science\". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Identifying and naming plants is the first step towards conserving and protecting the plants of New Guinea, said Dr Tim Utteridge of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"If we lose them, there's no way we can restore them from anywhere else, because they're just not found outside the island,\" he said. \"We have a real responsibility to conserve this unique plant life.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-53668124","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]

title: Beaver families win legal 'right to remain'
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fifteen families of beavers have been given the permanent \"right to remain\" on the River Otter in East Devon."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The decision was made by the government following a five-year study by the Devon Wildlife Trust into beavers' impact on the local environment.The Trust called it \"the most ground-breaking government decision for England's wildlife for a generation\". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It's the first time an extinct native mammal has been given government backing to be reintroduced in England.Environment minister Rebecca Pow said that in the future they could be considered a \"public good\" and farmers and landowners would pay to have them on their land. Beavers have the power to change entire landscapes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"They feel safer in deep water, so have become master makers of dams and pools. They build complex homes - known as lodges or burrows - with underwater entrances."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-53658375","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]

title: Deadly diseases from wildlife thrive when nature is destroyed
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Rats and bats that host pandemic pathogens like Covid-19 increase in damaged ecosystems, analysis shows."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The human destruction of natural ecosystems increases the numbers of rats, bats and other animals that harbour diseases that can lead to pandemics such as Covid-19, a comprehensive analysis has found."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The research assessed nearly 7,000 animal communities on six continents and found that the conversion of wild places into farmland or settlements often wipes out larger species. It found that the damage benefits smaller, more adaptable creatures that also carry the most pathogens that can pass to humans."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The assessment found that the populations of animals hosting what are known as zoonotic diseases were up to 2.5 times bigger in degraded places, and that the proportion of species that carry these pathogens increased by up to 70% compared with in undamaged ecosystems."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/aug/05/deadly-diseases-from-wildlife-thrive-when-nature-is-destroyed-study-finds","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]

title: New British planning reforms could seriously impact fight against climate change
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The government’s proposed reforms of the planning system will cost Britain decades in the fight against climate change and resign nature to “isolated fragments of land”, environmentalists have warned. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Countryside charities said plans to make new homes carbon neutral by as late as 2050 – beyond what scientists say will be a tipping point for climate change – as “pitiful” and dramatically less ambitious than previous ambitions scrapped by ministers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The government says the framework spelled out in its new planning white paper would “cut red tape” and create a “major boost” for construction firms while delivering more homes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Under the plans, unveiled by housing secretary Robert Jenrick, land would be categorised as either suitable for development, a “renewal” area, or protected. title: Japan's climate change efforts hindered by biased business lobby
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Japan’s powerful business lobby Keidanren is dominated by energy-intensive sectors that represent less than 10% of the economy, resulting in national policies that favour coal and hindering attempts to combat climate change, a new study said."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The influence of the country’s electricity, steel, cement, car and fossil fuel sectors undermines Japan’s attempts to meet its Paris Agreement commitments, according to the report by London-based data analysis company InfluenceMap. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Keidanren, which has close ties with the trade and industry ministry as well as other government bodies, sits on expert panels and other forums where government policies are debated. It has acted as a ‘central negotiating point’ on climate policy for two decades, the report said. While it claims to represent all of Japanese business, the claim “clearly should be questioned on climate/energy policy,” InfluenceMap said. It added the most powerful industries within Keidanren only employ about 2.7 million, while those with little influence employ 10 times that number. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lobbying and consultation by business groups will be critical next year when the government reviews its strategic energy plan."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read more "},{"type":"link","url":"https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-climate-change-japan-coal/japans-climate-change-efforts-hindered-by-biased-business-lobby-study-idUKKCN2511G4","children":[{"text":"here."}]},{"text":""}]}]

title: Italian Illustrators Reimagine Fairy Tales to Help Children Understand Climate Change
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Eight authors and illustrators at Studio Rebigo based in Genoa, Italy, selected 23 stories and set them in ruined ecosystems, to help next generations develop critical thinking. The group explored deforestation, plastic pollution, global warming and urbanization, through the drawings of dystopian environmental disasters. These retellings feature folktales like Little Red Riding Hood and Jack and the Beanstalk, and classics like Jules Verne’s \"Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea\", Hans Christian Andersen’s \"The Little Mermaid\", Grimms’ \"Hansel and Gretel\", Italo Calvino’s \"The baron in the trees\" and Frances Eliza Hodgson Burnett’s \"The Secret Garden\"."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“At a time when everyone was talking about the future, about aware youth, and about the kind of world they will inherit from us, it seemed fair to think about our target audience, so the generations to come and their parents who are currently our peers,” illustrator Alessandro Parodi explains. “Hence the question: what world and what stories will we leave them?” The book was designed for children, and all those who deal with them, from parents to teachers. “We don't want to teach anything, since we are still studying ourselves, but we hope the book can help readers develop critical thinking about these topics and eventually make them consider their little daily gestures.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read the full article "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.forbes.com/sites/emanuelabarbiroglio/2020/08/05/what-is-climate-change-explained-by-italian-illustrators-in-23-fairy-tales/#61b701b697e1","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":", and check out "},{"type":"link","url":"https://studiorebigo.myportfolio.com/casa","children":[{"text":"Studio Rebigo's website"}]},{"text":" while you're at it!"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"(Picture: Studio Rebigo)"}]}]
